awd_titl_txt: A Theoretical Framework for Understanding Strategic Behavior in Systems Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to improve understanding about the impact of strategic behaviors under incomplete information on systems engineering projects. The complexity of modern engineering projects requires coordinating the activities of thousands of individuals across multiple organizations. Systems engineering tackles this complexity through well-documented processes for hierarchically decomposing the problem, passing requirements down the hierarchy, subcontracting, etc. However, such systems engineering processes typically result in significant cost overruns and schedule slippages. These represent significant losses to society and, oftentimes, taxpayers (one estimate values such losses to the U.S. Department of Defense alone at over $200 million per day). This research project will question assumptions underlying current systems engineering processes and advance understanding needed to improve systems engineering practice. To enable further research on this important problem area, research tools and data produced as part of this project will be made available freely via web-based repositories. A workshop will be organized to address research and educational challenges in this area. Results of this research can impact the development of large-scale engineered systems of any kind, including aerospace, defense, transportation and energy systems.

In this project, systems engineering processes will be modeled as dynamic network games of incomplete information. This will be accomplished in three modeling steps covering: interactions between engineers in system and sub-system levels, hierarchical systems engineering processes, and dynamic systems engineering processes. The overall expected outcomes of this project are (i) a foundational theory of systems engineering that considers the strategic decision making and distributed information, and (ii) a theoretical evaluation of existing systems engineering processes according to various criteria measuring their robustness to strategic behavior. The specific outcomes include information systems and reward/penalty structures encountered in established systems engineering processes, principal and agent utilities capable of taking into account empirical behavioral characteristics, characterization of agent design abilities and how they relate to the uncertainty of the process outcome,  network game representation of established hierarchical systems engineering processes, characterization of hierarchical systems engineering network game equilibria, multi-stage network game representation of dynamic systems engineering processes, and characterization of dynamic systems engineering processes equilibria according to various criteria, e.g., the organizational utility at equilibrium, the total welfare of subsystem engineering teams, incentive compatibility, and more. The results of this project will be disseminated through publications, workshops, open source software, and an online data repository.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The major research goal of this project was to understand how individual incentives affect the outcome of complex systems engineering processes. More specifically, the team tried to understand to what extent the divergent personal motives of agents (contractors, component engineers, system engineers, managements, or the government) can explain the observed cost overruns and delays in the acquisition of large-scale systems (e.g., civil infrastructure, military aircrafts, space missions). The team followed an interdisciplinary approach that combined agent-based modeling, game theory, uncertainty quantification, machine learning, and Bayesian statistics.

The team conducted several studies published in major journal and conference proceedings. In chronological order, they conducted research on: (i) the effect of task complexity and problem-solving skills on design performance, (ii) the mathematical modeling of systems engineering processes, (iii) the mathematical modeling of large-scale system acquisition via bidding mechanisms, (iv) a data-driven analysis of schedule and cost growth in defense acquisition programs, (v)  a mathematical theory that explains the rationality behind design heuristics, and (vi) a statistical approach that extracts an engineer's knowledge graph from responses to numerical problems.

One of the most innovative outcomes of this project was the development of a mathematical theory of systems engineering processes that can be used to study the problem of optimal incentives (or mechanism design) involving two actors, e.g., a system engineer and component engineers. The theory predicts what is the best way for a system engineer to incentivize a component engineer depending on what they know about the complexity of the design task, the design skills of the component engineer, and the potential value of the final system. Of course, the modeled systems engineering process is an oversimplification of reality. However, to the best of the team?s knowledge, it is the first attempt to rigorously quantify the effect of incentives of the systems engineering outcome. It is a first step towards describing mathematically systems engineering processes in their full complexity. The theory was extended to study bidding mechanisms in defense acquisition programs enhancing our understanding of the differences between fixed price and cost-plus contracts.

 

Broder Impacts

The team has disseminated the research through several conferences and journal papers.  Also, the project has provided unique training opportunities for six graduate students, five in Mechanical Engineering and one in Business school. The engineering students were exposed to fields of knowledge that are not typically part of the standard curriculum, e.g., game theory, reinforcement learning. The project also provided training opportunities for undergraduate students in mechanical engineering. 

The developed theory of systems engineering provides quantitative explanations of the effect of incentive choice on the design outcome. The researchers used the theory to study the acquisition of major defense systems and they quantified the potential effect of different contracting mechanisms.

Finally, the team developed a statistical approach that quantifies an individual's knowledge from their responses to numerical problems. The method was applied to the problem of characterizing the weaknesses of engineering students from exam responses. The approach has potential applications on personalized learning.
